@rabbah, there is some discussion around not returning an HTTP code of 200 when the response is empty.

I was wrong about the race - wast thinking of a different kafka test suite. I don't see a race here. Inspecting one of the failed jenkins builds (pg2/1448), I see:

```
    [2017-04-16T20:01:07.292Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sending to topic 'Dinosaurs' msg 'Sun Apr 16 16:01:07 EDT 2017'
    [2017-04-16T20:01:17.301Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sending to topic 'Dinosaurs' msg 'Sun Apr 16 16:01:17 EDT 2017'
    [2017-04-16T20:01:18.305Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sending to topic 'Dinosaurs' msg 'Sun Apr 16 16:01:18 EDT 2017'
    [2017-04-16T20:01:23.598Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sent message: Dinosaurs[0][1]
    [2017-04-16T20:01:23.598Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sent message: Dinosaurs[0][0]
    [2017-04-16T20:01:23.598Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sent message: Dinosaurs[0][2]
```

The first three send requests are 10 seconds apart - each of these correspond to one send attempt per test. You'll see from the `sent` message that there was a delay sending these and the publisher didn't actually complete until 16 seconds after the very first send request.

Reasons TBD.
(@bjustin-ibm FYI.)

I reject that as non-nonsensical but willing to debate it if someone wants to take the opposing view (analog: express' `res.send()`).
 
Per https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/2132#issuecomment-293562946, the implementation follows the intended defaults and I updated the missing default in the docs for body.

@rabbah thanks for saying "we" instead of @paulcastro :-D

I forgot that important step.  Let me add a test.
New test succeed locally.  PG 1412

One potentially common scenario.  A developer quickly creates a webaction from an existing action (i.e. set web-export annotation to true), but leaves the action logic alone.   When the webaction is invoked without an extension (defaults to .http), the response will contain JSON that does not have a `body`, but does have one or more fields - none of which are `statusCode` or `headers`.  Currently, the status code is 200 with no body, which may lead to some false positives regarding the actual action success.

In this developer-error scenario, I suppose this could be viewed as a content type mismatch.  The request expected a webaction HTTP response, but actual response was free form webaction JSON.  Since the webaction invocation extension is involved in specifying content type, a response that does not adhere to the request is mismatched.

`return {statusCode: 400}`
`return {body: "..."}`
`return {headers: {"Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*"}}`
`return {}`

All are plausible and reasonable responses - which of these should be malformed?
It seems that trying to save the programmer from bad code is a separate concern better solved by a validation middleware (a la express) or tests.
pg1/1411 approved.

> The user should be aware they are in fact authorizing triggers to be fired on their behalf

I agree. Rather, I was trying to point out that I suspect that users won't intuit that an action invocation is happening on their behalf during trigger creation (from a feed), and that it doesn't really benefit them in a practical sense to know this is happening.

I agree that issue at hand is how to alert the programmer to bad code.  Will middleware automatically handle the content type checks?  I was thinking it did not and that it was up to the express developer to enforce any content type restrictions.

From the sample snippets above, I don't think any of those are malformed; the `statusCode` will default to 200 when not specified and the `body` and `header` fields are optional with no defaults.

The malformed JSON, when returned for a webaction .http invocation, I'm thinking of is something like:
```
return { name: "fred", status: "success", fieldA: "valueA" }
```

To invoke a web action and pass it the auth key is not sufficient. The validation of the key is required - somerwhere. We currently allow the controller to validate this key and pass on the corresponding namespace to the web action if it's valid (and no namespace otherwise). This is done now to allow API experimental to continue to operate as before. There was discussion and agreement to remove this feature although I don't think I noted this in an issue which I shall do.

So the desired `--web` feature discussed herein isn't really just about invoking a web action, you will need also the authorization key for the caller, right? Is the fact that it's part of a feed sufficiently different from say calling an arbitrary API call?

If the issue here is strictly with respect to entitlement (want to grant Activation rights but not CRUD), then should we focus on just solving that problem instead where a web action is just solving that problem for you indirectly? Or is it that a web action is the right solution to this problem and so perhaps we should just require that all feeds implement a web action as a way of handling the trigger life cycle management?

@rabbah Ahhh... I think I'm starting to see it. Just to be clear, what would be the value of `__OW_API_KEY` if we made the feed action a web action and called it as such from the CLI (as proposed here)? Are you saying that it would be the key for the action owner and not the caller?

I suspect that it's reasonable to require an empty dictionary or at least one of  `headers`, `body` or `statusCode` for a non-empty dictionary from an `http` web action. 

On the flip side, any testing at all will show that you've made a mistake when you get this wrongâ€¦

Yeah, testing will reveal something is wrong in the scenario described above, but the 200 status code without any body may not be sufficient to quickly lead to a content type mismatch root cause.  In this scenario, the webaction's activation results don't directly call out the content type mismatch; so I think the only logging that would call this out would be in the OpenWhisk controller log - something the developer won't have access to.

The other Kafka Connector test failure I've encountered is
```
services.KafkaConnectorTests > Kafka connector should send and receive a kafka message which sets up the topic FAILED
    java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException: Futures timed out after [10 seconds]
```
When the test has been successful, the wait times for the initial post are close to the 10 second limit; so if this is normal Kafka behavior for producers publishing a message to a new topic, then perhaps the timeout needs increasing.
```
services.KafkaConnectorTests > Kafka connector should send and receive a kafka message which sets up the topic STANDARD_OUT
    (0) Received 1. Took 8029 msec: List(Thu Apr 06 09:34:02 EDT 2017)

    (1) Received 1. Took 2 msec: List(Thu Apr 06 09:34:10 EDT 2017)

    (2) Received 1. Took 1 msec: List(Thu Apr 06 09:34:10 EDT 2017)

    (3) Received 1. Took 1 msec: List(Thu Apr 06 09:34:10 EDT 2017)

    (4) Received 1. Took 1 msec: List(Thu Apr 06 09:34:10 EDT 2017)


services.KafkaConnectorTests > Kafka connector should send and receive a kafka message which sets up the topic PASSED
```

I have the changes ready for review now. I have tested these changes on mac.

Here are the list of changes:

WSK CLI is downloaded from openwhisk/openwhisk-cli repo.
CLI is located at releases page on github in a zip format [here](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases).
These changes downloads zip file and unarchives it to
produce wsk executable file depending on the env.

```
ls -R /Users/Shared/nginx/cli/go/download/
mac/

/Users/Shared/nginx/cli/go/download//mac:
amd64/

/Users/Shared/nginx/cli/go/download//mac/amd64:
OpenWhisk_CLI-mac.zip  wsk*
```

We are loosing content.json file with these changes as its not available with cli built on GitHub. Do we need that file at `/Users/Shared/nginx/cli/go/download/`?

Also, would like to parameterize this url (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases/download/latest/OpenWhisk_CLI-latest-linux-amd64.zip) instead of hardcoding it to always get latest. Don't know the exact syntax and parameter name for that. Please help.

In the end, please provide your feedback/comments on ansible code structure, I have no expertise in Ansible or Enginx.

Changed formatting to:
**Activation ID** : 32 characters
**Action Name** : variable (largest name)  (width min: 5 , max: 50) . 
If length is > 50 : display first 46 chars + " ..."
**Status** : Failure or Success
**Start Time** : e.g. 2017-04-19 14:10:14 +0000 UTC 
**Duration [ms]** : variable width (highest number of digits), right aligned

example 1 :
```
$ wsk activation list
Activation ID                    Name    Status  Start Time                     Duration [ms]
de718b48af7b466aa2ded594d25c66ed action1 Success 2017-04-19 14:33:49 +0000 UTC   83
976cd0ec780a4d978b4258942e4076b8 action2 Success 2017-04-19 14:33:44 +0000 UTC   56

a20804dd4ef8459b923c7efbf6f36b3f action3 Success 2017-04-19 14:33:25 +0000 UTC  554
```
example 2 (long action names) :
```
$ wsk activation list
Activation ID                    Name                                               Status  Start Time                     Duration [ms]
56f1ae03da424a75b1e70fa7d73bb419 action-invoke-nodejsdefault-1492611019965          Success 2017-04-19 14:10:20 +0000 UTC     69
eb60f5a9098d4323b32c52d7bed478c7 action-invoke-nodejsdefault-1492611019965          Success 2017-04-19 14:10:20 +0000 UTC     85

0631ae9384c444ecbe128474fd50b6da action-invoke-nodejsdefault-1492610959946          Success 2017-04-19 14:09:20 +0000 UTC     50

b9fc32b971524869bd60f7ecc5ab4290 action-invoke-nodejsdefault-1492610899925          Success 2017-04-19 14:08:20 +0000 UTC     69
```

One design previously discussed is:   if you want others to invoke your action but not read the source, simply keep the action private but expose a REST API.
aka web action? :)

The issue was closed because the PR merged above fixes the "OK" bug for missing body. @mdeuser if you'd like to reopen the issue or create a new one to discuss whether to error on a missing code + body + headers, please do so.

For the record, I don't think you need access to the system logs to know what happened.

```
> cat t.js 
function main() { return { name: "fred", status: "success", fieldA: "valueA" } }
```

create the action
```
> wsk action create t t.js --web yes
```

and curl it
```
> curl -k https://guest.openwhisk/default/t -v
*   Trying 192.168.99.100...
* Connected to guest.openwhisk (192.168.99.100) port 443 (#0)
* TLS 1.2 connection using TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA
* Server certificate: *.openwhisk
> GET /default/t HTTP/1.1
> Host: guest.openwhisk
> User-Agent: curl/7.43.0
> Accept: */*
> 
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Server: nginx/1.11.13
< Date: Wed, 19 Apr 2017 17:55:42 GMT
< Content-Length: 0
< Connection: keep-alive
< 
* Connection #0 to host guest.openwhisk left intact
```

now get the activation
```
> lget
ok: got activation 472cc4dd39884e9381adfc6a04d4291d
{
    "namespace": "guest",
    "name": "t",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "subject": "guest",
    "activationId": "472cc4dd39884e9381adfc6a04d4291d",
    "start": 1492624542934,
    "end": 1492624542941,
    "duration": 7,
    "response": {
        "status": "success",
        "statusCode": 0,
        "success": true,
        "result": {
            "fieldA": "valueA",
            "name": "fred",
            "status": "success"
        }
    },
    "logs": [],
    "annotations": [
        {
            "key": "limits",
            "value": {
                "logs": 10,
                "memory": 256,
                "timeout": 60000
            }
        },
        {
            "key": "path",
            "value": "guest/t"
        }
    ],
    "publish": false
}
```

the developer can inspect the result of the activation and see the response - no system logs needed.

if you're referring to the client/caller - then that's a separate issue imo.

pg3/543 hit the kafka connector test failure.
@bjustin-ibm - Is this kafka delay expected when initially publishing a msg to a new topic?

Just taking a quick look at this, I don't think the topic is "new" in that it is created in the test - from what I can tell the test assumes the topic already exists. 

Regardless if the topic is newly-created or not, you _might_ expect that the consumer could be delayed in consuming the posted message, or may miss it entirely, if it had not yet been assigned the partition the message was produced to. This assignment is done only after some initial handshaking between the consumer and the broker(s) and, in my experience, can take numerous seconds for this assignment to happen.

That _may_ be what is happening here to explain the longer time to consume the first message posted. That being said, the timeout increased in this PR is on the producer side, which would not address this problem.

@mdeuser Are you sure the timeout was on the produce side, or was it on the consume side?

I'm not terribly familiar with the Java/Scala API for Kafka, but the correct fix may involve instead waiting until such time that the consumer actually gets partition assignments from the broker(s) before producing the messages. If that isn't possible with the API, then I suppose increasing the consumer timeout may help.

Or... the timeout really did happen on the producer, and I have no explanation for that ðŸ˜‰

In my specific scenario, the action in question is intended to be a feed action. 

It cannot be a web action because the value of `__OW_API_KEY` will be that of the action owner, not the caller as is currently needed. While this could be resolved by passing the correct key as a parameter to the action, this increases the changes needed in the CLI to make `wsk trigger create -f <feed>` continue to work, and really special cases feed actions that are web actions, likely requiring a new flag like `--web` for the user to know about and use in order to get the CLI to behave correctly. 

As @rabbah alludes to above, having an API in front of the non-shared action (whether automatically with a web action or otherwise) makes the situation even worse. While we _could_ special case it in the CLI, REST API users would have no clue about the REST call and the correct dance steps they need to perform in order to create a new trigger from this feed.

> While this could be resolved by passing the correct key as a parameter to the action, this increases the changes needed in the CLI to make wsk trigger create -f <feed> continue to work

doesn't the feed today receive the key of the caller already?
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/cli/go-whisk-cli/commands/trigger.go#L155

So while the `__OW_API_KEY` is the owner's key - the action already receives - by the feed lifecycle contract - the user (caller's) key.

@bjustin-ibm note that from the logs I posted - the issue is that the post (producer) was delayed (by 16 seconds - before the producer succeeded).


```
[2017-04-16T20:01:07.292Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sending to topic 'Dinosaurs' msg 'Sun Apr 16 16:01:07 EDT 2017'
...
[2017-04-16T20:01:23.598Z] [DEBUG] [??] [KafkaProducerConnector] sent message: Dinosaurs[0][1]
```
Interesting. I was not aware of that, or stopped being aware of it when we switched over to use the `__OW_API_KEY` environment variable in our feed actions. ðŸ¤”

so then problem solved? activate only can be solved by web actions, you get the user key, you can validate it, and apply business logic... we would mandate that all feed lifecycle managements are just APIs calls with a fixed schema?

In this case, I don't know what might cause the delay to produce a message, other than a laggy network, or slow broker(s) handling the initial producer handshake. In this case, I can't think of anything better than simply increasing the timeout value.

I'm not sure this is even possible, but are there kakfa metrics we can glean that might show where this delay is coming from?
https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitoring-kafka-performance-metrics/

Yes I think that may work. The other key info we need is the namespace (to construct the trigger URL) but that already gets passed along as part of the `triggerName` parameter.  What bothers me though is that at some point in the past we specifically changed the feed action code to stop ~using the `authKey` parameter in favor of using `__OW_API_KEY` and stopped~ parsing the namespace out of the `triggerName` parameter in favor of using `__OW_NAMESPACE`. I'm a little concerned about why we did that, and will undoing it take us a step backward.

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-package-kafka/pull/103/files

In any case, I'll start implementing it with a web action and see if I can't make it fly. We will still need to teach the CLI (and all other clients really) how to invoke feed actions that are web actions...

**Update:** We starting using `__OW_API_KEY` to stop using `whisk. getAuthKey()`

The reason we could not use the namespace that was passed in with the triggername was because it would often pass in _ for the namespace which was not unique.  We used the __OW_NAMESPACE to get the real resolved namespace for _.  We definitely still need the resolved namespace name.  We use the namespace as part of the id when storing the cloudant and kafka trigggers in cloudant.  It needs to be unique.

@mdeuser I'm not familiar with this client, but the one I use (Python) allows you to set some debug flags which cause it to log lots of interesting information. Perhaps your client has something similar.

You can call the openwhisk API for namespace/list with the key and get back the namespace. This is for example a way for the feed API to validate an authorization token.

> Update: We starting using __OW_API_KEY to stop using whisk. getAuthKey()

This was just wrong :) should have used the value from the trigger life cycle event. Sorry if I missed that change. But to @jasonpet's point, the outlined solution in this comment will address `_`.

To teach the CLI to call a feed action I suggest we work through what it means to say that the life cycle handler is always a HTTP/REST call. It should be cleaner, intuitively.

We are able to build the CLIs for all the operating systems, and they are publish on this page https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-cli/releases. What this PR needs to do is to pick up the one, that fits the hosting OS.

This looks like it adds ContainerPool and Container abstractions but doesn't yet use them in anything but tests? It's laying the groundwork for creating a DockerContainer and other Container implementations? I'm interested in a KubernetesContainer implementation and want to make sure I'm following the proposed changes correctly.

OK - we're communicating across purposes. Let me try with a blank slate.

When a developer is building and deploying openwhisk locally, by _default_ is to build exactly 1 version of the CLI. This version is bundled with the edge router. We did this to cut down the build time.

A developer may override this behavior and build all 3 binaries of the CLI regardless of the host environment. In this case, the edge router should bundle all the binaries.

In essence, since the building of the binary is now _not_ part of this core repo, and since the cost is therefore roughly free, the edge router should bundle _all_ the binaries by default.

In the CLI repo, this is where I would allow a developer to build only 1 binary as opposed to all of the versions.

So what I would like to see are these features:
1. by default, the edge router bundles into the edge all available versions of the CLI binary from a well defined source.
2. with an optional override, the edge router bundles from a local source the binaries that may be available.

The second feature is to allow a developer to build the CLI locally and bundle it with the edge router, and hence decouples the bundling, optionally, from the source we publish.
Indeed - this is part of the plan to incrementally introduce an entirely new reactive container pool and load balancing algorithm.

Thanks for the question and interest in doing a comparison. We have not yet published benchmarks or a benchmarking methodology. This is however something of interest for the community and the question has come up before in various pull request discussions.

After discussing with @mdeuser over the design on how to specify here the final proposal

1. have an optional flag to specify the content type extension for the response when forming the web action url to be use by the API Gateway
2. change the default to .json extension
```
  --response-type CONTENT_TYPE_EXTENSION possible values json, http, text, svg (default json)
```

```
$ wsk api create -h

Usage:
  wsk api create ([BASE_PATH] API_PATH API_VERB ACTION] [--response-type EXTENSION] | --config-file CFG_FILE)  [flags]

Flags:
  -n, --apiname string         Friendly name of the API; ignored when CFG_FILE is specified (default BASE_PATH)
  -c, --config-file CFG_FILE   CFG_FILE containing API configuration in swagger JSON format
  --response-type EXTENSION EXTENSION with possible values json, http, text, svg (default .json)

```
This will allow the following examples:
```
wsk api create /store /pets get myaction
 (This default to --response-type json)
wsk api create /store /pets get myaction   --response-type json
wsk api create /store /pets post myaction --response-type http
wsk api create /store /pets get myaction   --response-type html
wsk api create /store /pets get myaction   --response-type svg
```

This issue appears to be happening again. 
Earlier today a health build failed multiple times (not successively) due to seemingly this error, where it tried to delete a package but the package deletion failed because it still contained an action within it. 

The last failure was in the test
"system.basic.WskConsoleTests.Wsk Activation Console should show an activation log message for hello world"
where it failed due to:
`
ERROR: deleting asset failed for samples: org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: wsk -i --apiversion v1 package delete --auth ... /_/samples error: Unable to delete package 'samples': Package not empty (contains 1 entity) (code xxx) exit code: 153 was not equal to 0
`

A couple builds before the above failure the test
"system.basic.WskPackageTests.Wsk Package should perform package binds so parameters are inherited"
failed due to: 
`
Starting test Wsk Package should perform package binds so parameters are inherited at 2017-04-21 16:27:03.146
